I think the misunderstanding here is that we aren't talking about those 'failing calculus' as the only ones who might be inspired by alternate pathways. We also encourage people to have more civility in discourse around math education. Let's address ideas, not attack people, please!

I haven't heard anyone mention discrete mathematics as a high school pathway option. So we say it here! Calculus doesn't have to be the pinnacle of HS math. It can be an option, but many other options would give more students a view that math can be interesting and joyful.

Modernizing the curriculum shouldn't be controversial. It was advocated in the Common Vision report by leading math societies at the college level (@maanow @amermathsoc @TheSIAMNews @MathAMATYC @AmstatNews), which stated "The status quo is unacceptable." https://t.co/l7EEOU3ZjJ

@RisetoClimate @PFriedling @rustneversleepz @theresphysics @wim_carton Soil respiration models generally have a ‚ÄòQ10‚Äô temperature sensitivity: Rh = SOC * decay_rate * Q10 ^ ((Temperature - 15)/10)

With a warming/control experiment you can re arrange the math and get the Q10 value. Generally ~ 2

@nacrila As a jr in the field (student or otherwise) it‚Äôs not on you to figure out how to change the field. You just have to figure out how to work it. Sometimes that means going at a problem/domain sideways if frontal assult is closed to you.

Hense someone math trained goes into eco.

I got a PhD from an Earth System Science Dept and am TT in an environmental engingeering department with several of the classical academic hallmarks of success. (NSF CAREER, h-index, Nature pub)

Could I have cut it in Math? Multiple gatekeepers said no. I'll never know.

But the next year I stopped applying to math PhD programs and started applying to labs doing soil modeling.

Am I bitter? Yes. 

Am I happier? Probably also yes.

I was completely devistated (cryed through the entire meeting). I was 2yrs out of a math BS and thought of myself as applied math, having minimal bio background. I could not bring myself to agree to switch to bio and was not admitted.

I interviewed for one math-bio program where you would take a ‚Äòbridge‚Äô year then enroll in either the math or biology PhD program. The director pulled me asside and said I would be admitted, if I agreed to go biology yr 2.

Almost all of the women whom I knew in college who were high preforming mathematics students became K-12 teachers or homemakers. I can come up with no examples from the men.

I switched fields because I couldn‚Äôt get into a math PhD program. https://t.co/oXVwQU7dVN

Chpt9: Math (as a field) has a justice problem: Implicit bias of who can do math. Cultural framing of classical problems. Tracking in education freezing out curiosity. There are structural and person calls for justice that need to be addressed. 10/n

RT @SarahTaber_bww: More data on how most food price inflation is from *food co's padding their profit margins.*

Not from rising labor & r‚Ä¶

Chpt7: Folks struggle to reach internal and external rewards. Internal aligns with personal growth and addresses need for meaning. Math values struggle and persistence (similar to science more generally). Hard to teach to students focused on grades but possible. 8/n

More complicated emotions with this chapter. Axioms are critical here; while they are fairly easy to identify in mathematics (but WHY does 1+1=2) they are extremely complicated to construct in reality. This is why math often works with ‚Äòtoy‚Äô examples. https://t.co/IUF9X0cThJ
Chpt6: Permanence is a universal human need soaking to stability and safety. Math theorems (once established) are fundamentally permanent and trust in reason. 7/n
Chpt5: Math is beautiful and that beauty come in many flavors: sensory, wonder, insight, and transcendent. 6/n

The concept of mathematical play and gatekeeping; who gets to do Math. Has me sitting here choking up as I write this tweet. 

Really ironic that I ended up in engineering, a discipline that is well known for route application of calculations. #LifeIsStrange

I found questions that were math-adjacent, where I ‚Äòabused algebra‚Äô to understand patterns in data/theory. I dove deep in to soils and gave up my identity as a mathematician (whole story here about applying to grad school).

I got to college and enrolled in a math degree (w/ a tone of placement credit, skipped Calc, ODEs, and Linear to started with Real Analysis). I showed my notebooks to my advisor who wasn‚Äôt quite sure what to do with it.

@mathyawp Chpt2: Math provides a framework to ask questions and explore logical connections in our world. This lays in contrast to route calculations that are often emphasized in teaching. Connections to cultural puzzles and place-based knowledge provide entry points. 3/n

TBH, I was never terribly bothered by wave-particle duality, entanglement, or any of the other quantum weirdness. But General Relativity never clicked. Maybe it was just the math: PDEs were obvious to me, while I was never able to scratch the surface of Differential Geometry.
